messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-31T12:13:48Z
## Message ID: 20201031-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux have remained above 1000 pfu since 2020-10-26T07:45Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels since 2020-10-25T12:00Z have been caused by a high speed stream that was detected at L1 on 2020-10-23 (see notifications 20201025-AL-001, 20201027-AL-001, 20201029-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-10-25T12:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 21, 2020 - October 27, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-28T20:56:33Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-10-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201028-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period.  There was one back-sided C-type CME with speed of 540 km/s.

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods:
2020-10-21T06:00Z to 2020-10-21T09:00Z; 
2020-10-23T18:00Z to 2020-10-24T09:00Z; 
2020-10-25T12:00Z to 2020-10-25T15:00Z; 
2020-10-25T18:00Z to 2020-10-25T21:00Z; 
2020-10-26T03:00Z to 2020-10-26T06:00Z; 
2020-10-26T12:00Z to 2020-10-26T15:00Z; 
2020-10-27T06:00Z to 2020-10-27T09:00Z.
The increases in geomagnetic activity on 2020-10-23 and thereafter were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2020-10-23; the solar wind speed reached values in excess of 500 km/s for the remainder of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2020-10-25T12:00Z and remained at elevated levels for the rest of the reporting period (see notifications 20201025-AL-001, 20201027-AL-001). The elevated flux levels were the result of the aforementioned coronal hole high speed stream that increased geomagnetic activity.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate during the reporting period due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2020-10-26T18:09Z     ~540            C              -151/-3                26                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-11-03T23:59Z

The solar activity for the outlook period is expected to be between low and minor levels. Active Region 2778 currently has a Beta-Gamma magnetic classification and has produced numerous C-class flares; AR2778 should rotate off the Earth-facing disk in the latter half of the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be between low to minor levels for the outlook period. A S-type (<500 km/s) CME associated with a filament eruption near N30E10 on the Earth-facing disk occurred late into the evening of 2020-10-26; current estimates place an arrival at Earth sometime around 2020-11-01T00:00Z (+/- 7 hours). The arrival signature is likely to be complicated due to the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream arriving the same day. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron fluxes are likely to remain elevated for the remainder of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 14, 2020 - October 20, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-21T19:36:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-10-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201021-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

An S-type (<500 km/s) CME that was first seen in the coronagraphs at 2020-10-15T11:24Z arrived at STEREO A around 2020-10-17T14:42Z as detected by STEREO A IMPACT instrument. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-10-27T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the upcoming week. Active region 2776 is expected to remain visible on the Earth-facing disk for the next several days. An additional active region has started to emerge from the eastern limb as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO. Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the upcoming week. The Kp index has reached 4 during the synoptic period of 2020-10-21T06:00Z-09:00Z. A series of northern mid-latitude and equatorial coronal hole structures may become geoeffective as early as 2020-10-22.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 07, 2020 - October 13, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-14T20:31:26Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-10-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201014-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 2 for the reporting period. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2020-10-07 and 2020-10-10 (see notifications 20201007-AL-001 and 20201010-AL-001). These elevated flux levels at the beginning of the reporting period are associated with the near coincident arrivals of a slow S-type (<500 km/s) CME that was first seen in the coronagraphs at 2020-09-30T12:09Z and a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2020-10-07; the arrivals of these transients resulted in an average solar wind speed around 410 km/s early 2020-10-08.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-10-20T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be at low to minor levels for the upcoming week. Active regions 2774 and 2775 should remain on the Earth-facing disk for the next few days, with an additional unnumbered active region rotating in from the Eastern limb. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. Coronal hole high speed streams are unlikely during the outlook period as there are no significant structures across the Earth-facing disk.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 30, 2020 - October 06, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-07T20:09:28Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-10-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201007-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2020-09-30T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2020-09-30T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2020-10-01T09:00Z-12:00Z, 2020-10-05T18:00Z-21:00Z, and 2020-10-06T03:00Z-06:00Z. These slight increases in geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2020-09-27 and the arrival of an S-type (<500 km/s) CME with ID 2020-09-30T12:09:00-CME-001. A small interplanetary shock associated with the arrival of this CME was observed at L1 starting at 2020-10-05T16:42Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained above the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the majority of the reporting period (see notifications 20200930-AL-001, 20201002-AL-001, and 20201004-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2020-09-27.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-10-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-10-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the upcoming week. There are currently no significant active regions on the solar surface as seen in the available imagery. A continual enhancement in the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES may be observed towards the beginning of the upcoming week. The integral electron flux has exceeded the 1000 pfu threshold starting at 2020-10-07T14:05Z (see notification 20201007-AL-001). Geomagnetic activity is expected to be between low and minor levels for the upcoming week.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-10-07T17:18:51Z
## Message ID: 20201007-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-10-07T14:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by an S-type CME with ID 2020-09-30T12:09:00-CME-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-10-07T14:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

This ongoing event is preceded by a radiation belt enhancement first observed at 2020-09-28T07:55Z which is associated with a high speed stream starting on 2020-09-27 (see notifications 20200928-AL-003, 20200930-AL-001, 20201002-AL-001, and 20201004-AL-001).

The S-type CME with ID 2020-09-30T12:09:00-CME-001 was observed in SOHO coronagraph imagery as a faint halo. A source region for this CME could not be located due to data gaps in the available EUV imagery. A small interplanetary shock associated with the arrival of this CME was observed at L1 starting at 2020-10-05T16:42Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.
